newsitem.title: USA: DenAmerica sees tough same store comparisons.
newsitem.headline: DenAmerica sees tough same store comparisons.

text.p: DenAmerica Corp said Wednesday the withdrawal from the Denny's value pricing strategy in 1996 will have a slightly negative impact on same store sales results through the third quarter of 1997.
The value price strategy, which the company ended in October, increased sales, meaning comparisons for the quarters until October will be difficult.

The company, largest U.S. franchisee of Denny's restaurants and owner and franchisor of the Black-eyed Pea restaurant chain, said it expects restaurant operating margins to improve as food and labor costs decrease as a percentage of revenues.

DenAmerica said operating results for Black-eyed Pea, which it acquired in July 1996, exceeded internal projections and it intends to expand by adding restaurants in core markets, which should result in additional media and operational efficiencies.

Earlier the company posted a fourth quarter loss of $187,000, or $0.01 a share, on revenues of $77.7 million, compared with a net loss of $1,122,000, or $0.16 per share, on revenues of $20.8 million for the year-ago period.
DenAmerica was formed in March 1996 by the merger of Denwest Restaurant Corp and American Family Restaurants.
